question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Here we are working with \(x=0.9\) and \(a=1\). We find that the error takes the following value

\[\begin{aligned} |\text{Error}| \leq \frac{M}{2}(0.9-1)^2 = \frac{M}{200}\end{aligned}\]

where \(M\) is the maximum value of the absolute value of the second derivative on the interval [0.9, 1]. In other words, we would like to estimate how large the second derivative can be on this interval.

Given that

\[\begin{aligned} |f''(x)| = \left| \frac{-1}{x^{2}} \right| = \frac{1}{x^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

and since this is a decreasing function on the interval [0.9, 1] we can deduce that the maximum value it takes on the interval is at \(x=0.9\) and hence

\[\begin{aligned} M = \frac{1}{0.9^{2}} = \frac{100}{81}\end{aligned}\]

This allows us to find the upper bound on the error:

\[\begin{aligned} |\text{Error}| \leq \frac{\frac{100}{81}}{200} = \frac{1}{162}\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
In this problem, you will approximate \(\ln(0.9)\) in two ways: one using linear approximation and the other using quadratic approximation. You may find it useful to draw the graph of \(\ln(x)\) for \(x\) near 1 to help you answer some parts of this question.

b) Use the formula

\[\begin{aligned} |\mbox{Error}| \le \frac{M}{2}(x - a)^{2},\end{aligned}\]

where \(M\) > 0, to estimate an error bound for your approximation of \(\ln(0.9)\) in part (a). It will be useful to remember how to find such an \(M\).
